thread.title: Where You’ve Seen Beyoncé’s Pregnancy Reveal Photo Before | Vanity Fair
thread.title_full: Where You’ve Seen Beyoncé’s Pregnancy Reveal Photo Before | Vanity Fair

author: Kenzie Bryant
title: Where You’ve Seen Beyoncé’s Pregnancy Reveal Photo Before | Vanity Fair
text: Where You’ve Seen Beyoncé’s Pregnancy Reveal Photo Before Another high-concept art performance by the artiste . by View on Instagram Beyoncé pulled off another surprise drop, but instead of an album, it’s a pregnancy announcement. It’s her second surprise reveal, having managed a similarly unexpected one at the 2011 MTV Video Music Awards when she was pregnant with daughter Blue Ivy Carter , who is now five. This time, the announcement was delivered through a high-concept photo. The singer revealed in a carefully worded caption that she’s having twins, but the image is the important part. Between the veil, her body’s position, the floral wreath, and the saturated colors she chose, the picture looks very familiar. Let’s take a brief walk through art history—including Beyoncé’s own visual oeuvre and trace the steps back to this glorious day. From Heritage Images/Hulton Archive/Getty Images. The Birth of Venus, c1482-1846. Left, from Hulton Fine Art Collection, right, from DEA Picture Library, both from Getty Images. Two 15th-century paintings portraying the Virgin Mary and her child. Right, from the Hulton Fine Art Collection/Getty Images; Context/Caption: Left, a poster from Beyoncé’s “Mrs. Carter World Tour;” Right, a portrait of Queen Elizabeth I from the National Portrait Gallery. Beyoncé is practiced mirroring women of cultural importance, here styling the Mrs. Carter Show World Tour art after Queen Elizabeth I’s portrait. A more sculptural take on the Catholic references, this time in her video for “Mine ft. Drake.” Courtesy of Sean Kelly Gallery, New York. Centering a person in front of a floral background almost looks like a real-world rendering of a Kehinde Wiley painting, like his Dacia Carter from 2012. © Petra Collins/ Wonderland Magazine Some have pointed out the similarities with artist Petra Collins’s work, such as this fall 2016 cover of Wonderland featuring Kim Kardashian West . From Splash News. This is a video still of a veiled Beyoncé used as stage-projection art for her Formation tour in New York in June 2016. Beyoncé and those Technicolor florals in her video for “Hymn for the Weekend,” made in collaboration with Coldplay.
